loans.name: Grace Abaya

texts.en: Aunty Grace sells general goods like tins of milk, milo, fish, soaps, soft drinks and the like. Her market is very vibrant in that she sells to a large group of people. She however needs capital for expansion. She is therefore seeking a loan of $1000.00 from Kiva to make this expansion a reality. She is very capable of paying it back since she has knowledge of simple accounting and loan management.

loans.use: Grace would like to expand her current business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Teresiah Wanjiku intends to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas is 63 years old and has seven children. The loss of his first wife and two sons, who assisted him in taking care of the younger children, brought hardship to his life. He decided to join GHAPE in 1999. He received his first loan of $30, which he invested in the production of window frames, iron doors and the sale of palm wine. His community has benefited substantially from his iron door business in particular; robbery is very rampant and with the availability of iron doors, thieves find it difficult to break into houses. He also supplies palm wine for celebrations and to small retailers.

Given a loan of $1200, he plans to buy a filling machine, iron rods and expand the size of his raffia palm bush for increased production of palm wine.

loans.use: Buying of welding materials and sale of palm wine.

loans.name: Raihona

texts.ru:
Raihona lives with her husband and their 4 children in Lakkon village. Her husband has no permanent employment and does odd jobs. To help him provide for the family 4 years ago Raihona decided to start selling children's clothing and footwear. Profits from this business help with many expenses for the kids and other family needs. Raihona has no permanent trading place. She travels to the neighboring villages to sell her goods. Previously her husband took out a loan from Microinvest and used it to buy, process and dry apricots. Dried apricots were sold with good profits. Raihona is applying for another loan to farther expand her business.

Translated from Russian by [Elena Sheyner, Kiva Volunteer.

Райхона живет со своим мужем и с детьми в кишлаке Лаккон. Ее муж работает разнорабочим и постоянного места работы у него нет. У Райхоны 4 детей. Чтобы поддержать мужа Райхона 4 года назад решила заняться бизнесом. В качестве товара для продажи она выбрала детскую одежду и обувь. Прибыль от бизнеса помогает решить проблемы семьи, совершаются многие расходы на детей. Постоянного места для торговли нет и она ездит по окрестным кишлакам. В Микроинвест первый займ получил ее муж и он был потрачен на переработку и сушку абрикосов. Переработанный абрикос продали и получили хорошую прибыль. Далее Райхона решила взять займ на расширение своего бизнеса. Сейчас она собирается получить новый займ на дальнейшее расширение бизнеса.

loans.use: to expand the business

loans.name: Celsa

texts.es:
Celsa C. is 29 years old and married. She lives in a humble home with her husband Pedro Villalba who is 36 years old and helps with the income of the house. Celsa has a dispensary in her house, and her husband is a specialist in the preparation of chacinados. They have 2 children, 3 and 5 years old, who make up the harmonious family life.

Celsa and her husband manage the dispensary where they sell all types of every day items such as sugar, milk, meat, eggs, vegetables, etc, and a special compliment of chacinados which Pedro is in charge of. He prepares sausages, mortadela, ham, cold cuts, etc. When the company where Pedro worked had financial problems and collapsed, he was left unemployed, so he decided, along with his wife, to learn this business for himself.

The experience of 10 years of sales of these products, the knowledge of the consumer market, and the necessity to survive, are some of the pillars that sustain these enterprising people. They have hired other unemployed people, experimenting in the preparation of chacinados, so the enterprise is already giving work to others. The small company produces according to demand so there is no set schedule, nor days of work. They make the sales in the dispensary and by request. Today Celsa is requesting a loan to buy a meat shredding machine. The dream of these enterprising business owners is to offer the opportunity of work to many unemployed youths in the area.

Celsa C. de 29 años, es casada, vive en una humilde vivienda con su cónyuge el señor Pedro Villalba de tiene 36 años quien ayuda con los ingresos de la casa. Celsa tiene una despensa en su casa, su marido es especialista en la elaboración de los chacinados. Tienen 2 hijos menores de edad, de 3 y 5 años respectivamente, quienes comparten la armoniosa vida familiar. Celsa y su cónyuge, atienden la despensa donde venden todo tipo de artículos de primera necesidad, como azúcar, leche, carne, huevos, hortalizas, etc. y un complemento especial de ventas es la de chacinados de la cual se encarga exclusivamente don Pedro. El elabora chorizos, mortadela, fiambre, jamón etc. Cuando la empresa donde trabajaba don Pedro, tuvo problemas financieros y quebró, el quedó desempleado, decidió con su esposa emprender por cuenta propia esta actividad. La experiencia de 10 años en la venta de estos productos, el conocimiento del mercado consumidor, y la necesidad de sobrevivir, son algunos de los pilares que sostiene a estos emprendedores. Para producir calidad han contratado a otros desempleados experimentados en esta actividad (elaboración de chacinados), o sea que el emprendimiento ya está dando trabajo a otras personas. La microempresa produce de acuerdo a la demanda por lo tanto no existe horario, ni días de trabajo. Las ventas las realizan en la despensa y bajo pedido, hoy día Celsa está solicitando un crédito que será destinado a la compra de una máquina trituradora de carne además de los ingredientes para la elaboración para la compra de carne, especias. etc. El sueño de estos micros emprendedores es ofrecer la oportunidad de trabajo a muchos jóvenes desempleados de la zona.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: Buy a meat shredder

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Mrs. Rita O. is 30 years old.  She is married with 2 children and lives in Benin City, Nigeria.  She runs a business center where she types and makes photocopies for people living in her community.  She spent 2 years learning the business before she started her own in 2005.  She is seeking a loan of $475 to buy more computers for typing.  She is grateful.

loans.use: To buy more computers

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal U., 36, and her husband, Chanthoeun Noy, have been married since 1990. They have five children: two sons and three daughters. Two of their children are studying in the local school, and one of Sophal’s daughters is helping her weave silk at home. Sophal and her family live on an island of the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. Sophal has been a silk weaver since she was 16 years old. It's a skill she learned from her neighbor. Her husband is a fisherman and also does farming. He also helps Sophal weave silk when he has free time.

Sophal is requesting her seventh loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $400. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials to continue her silk production and set up a new loom for her daughter. As Sophal has successfully repaid previous loans, we feel sure she will repay this new loan as well.

loans.use: To buy silk materials and prepare loom

loans.name: Kabowa 2 (E) Group

texts.en:
Aisha is 32 years old and runs a small poultry farm. When time permits, she also works in a beauty salon. Aisha will use her portion of the loan to buy chickenfeed and more chicks to raise. She will use the income they produce to bring electricity to her home and build a new poultry house. Amina, Esther and Carol all sell produce in the local market, and will use their portion of the loan to buy more items to sell to their customers.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more chicks, chickenfeed and produce

loans.name: Silverio

texts.en:
Silverio A. lives near the center of the town of Luque. He is married and has older children. Silverio works making baking goods to sell for profit and has been doing so for the past six years.

Siverio is asking for a loan in order to fully amplify his business. With access to an industrial kitchen he will be able to make many more baked goods and increase his profits. The conditions in which his small number of employees work will be bettered and profits will increase.

loans.use: To buy an industrial kitchen.

loans.name: Budumbuli West E A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Cissy N.. She is currently in the business of selling soft drinks and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge. Cissy is 27 years old and is single. She has 1 child and her child goes to school. Each week, Cissy makes approximately UGX 42000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to cater for her personal needs and save the rest Cissy has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Cissy is joined in her small group by Prossy Wesogna and Fatuma N.. Prossy Wesogna has a business selling used shoes and wants to stock more shoes. Fatuma N. is currently operating a business selling used clothes and wants a loan to increase stock.

loans.use: To add capital to soft drink business and boost it

loans.name: Jessica

texts.es:
Ms. Jessica M. Rengífo belongs to the Bank of Township “Alfonso Ugarte.” She lives in the region of San Martin and Province of San Martin, district of la Banda de Shilcayo Tarapoto,. Her home is located en el Jr. Jose Carlos Mariategui No. 159 and her business is located in el Jr. Raymond No. 292 de Tarapoto, where she lends her services doing Cosmotology.

The opportunity of a loan from Manuela Ramos has permitted her to renovate the furniture and supplies she uses in her beauty salon that generates income for the past 8 years and permits her to get necessities for her family.

With the credit of 800 soles that is paid over the 6 months, she would buy new seat covers and buy blow dryers.

Ms. Jessica lives with her husband and her 2 kids. She hired someone to help her in her business, at times even her husband sometimes supports her economically with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Mariah of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Jessica M. R. pertenece al Banco Comunal “Alfonso Ugarte” vive en la Región San Martín y Provincia de San Martín, distrito de la Banda de Shilcayo Tarapoto, su domicilio está ubicado en el Jr. José Carlos Mariátegui Nº 159 y su negocio se ubica en el Jr. Raymondi Nº 292 de Tarapoto, en cuyo local presta servicios como cosmetóloga.

La oportunidad de un préstamo en Manuela Ramos le ha permitido renovar los muebles y maquinaria que utiliza en su salón de belleza que durante 8 años le genera ingresos que le permiten cubrir necesidades de su familia.

Con el crédito por S/. 800.00 que será pagado el 6 meses, mandara a confeccionar nuevas fundas para los mubles donde esperan le turno sus clientes asimismo comprará una secadora eléctrica para cabello.

La señora Jessica vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos, en el negocio le ayuda un personal que contrató, asimismo su esposo en algunos momentos aporta también económicamente para implementar su negocio.

loans.use: With the loan she will buy a hair dryer among other things for her business.

loans.name: Fabian

texts.es:
Fabián works marketing seasonal merchandise with his wife. He has a small son. His residence this located in the poor zone called Sopocachi of the city of La Paz. The house belongs to his grandparents.

This is the fourth time that he has requested a loan with Impro. The amount will be used to purchase merchandise (women's clothing and some household goods for the home). Due to the profitability of his business, the determination of this micro-businessman and his experience in commerce, the client is eligible to receive this loan.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Fabián trabaja comercializando mercadería con su esposa de acuerdo a la temporada, tiene un hijo pequeño. Su domicilio esta ubicado en la zona bajo Sopocachi de la ciudad de La Paz, la casa pertenece a sus abuelos.

Es la cuarta vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, el monto será destinado para compra de mercadería (ropa de mujer, y algunos enseres para el hogar). Debido a la rentabilidad de su negocio, la determinación de este micro empresario y su experiencia en el comercio, el cliente es apto para acceder a este crédito.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for resale, specifically women's clothing and some household goods for the home.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena has a small shoe sales business at the busy Central Market in Melitopol, Ukraine. She has been in business for over 10 years and currently sells a nice selection of women’s shoes. She has a well-equipped kiosk and offers high quality service to her customers. Eventually, Elena would love to expand her business by opening an additional sales location. Elena is married and has one son.

Elena has requested a loan to add to her working capital and help purchase summer shoes. While shoes are always in demand, Elena can increase her sales by offering seasonal styles. This loan will allow her to continue investing in her business so she can further increase her profits.

loans.use: Add to working capital and purchase summer inventory

loans.name: Jamila's Group

texts.en:
Jamila baji is the wife of T. H. and they live in the city of Kasur, Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house, and is the mother of three sons. Her first son works in a factory and her other two sons help their father in his tea shop. She successfully completed loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan) in the past. Now she is applying for a loan for her husband’s tea shop business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Bani baji wants a loan for her vegetable business. Sakina baji wants a loan for her decorative embroidery business. Shumaila baji wants a loan for her mobile phone repair shop. Nasreen baji wants a loan for her car workshop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Khatira

texts.en: Khatira (her husband is pictured) is a mother of three children. She was born in 1986. Khatira is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Agdam region in Azerbaijan. She has settled in the Absheron region. Her husband has been as a taxi driver for 10 years. Now this family needs a loan of $1,200 to buy spare parts for improving their business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Elizabeth Esther

texts.es:
La señora  Elizabeth Esther, tiene 38 años, es madre soltera, estudió educación secundaria completa, no siguió estudiando porque siempre se ha dedicado al negocio, tiene 01 niña de 06 años, estudia 1er grado de Primaria, vive en el Distrito de Trujillo, en la Provincia de Trujillo en el Departamento de La Libertad.

Para ayudarse económicamente, antes tenía un negocio de verduras en el mercado La Hermelinda, lo dejó hace 06 años porque tenía que cuidar a su hija. Ahora trabaja en las mañanas en el mercado Maribel, en el cual vende verduras y por las tardes ofrece mazamorra, además lava ropa a particulares. Tiene 09 años trabajando en el Movimiento Manuela Ramos, una señora la invitó a participar en el Banco Comunal “MUJERES AL ÉXITO II” ella decidió pertenecer a este Banco porque quería incrementar capital, del mismo modo hay facilidades para poder trabajar y con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 que recibió compró verduras, maíz, azúcar, arroz, leche, etc.

Con este préstamo de S/. 500.00, que cancelará en un plazo de 04 meses, tiene pensado invertir este dinero en la compra de verduras, azúcar, pasas, maíz, etc.
La socia sueña con tener un puesto propio de verduras porque siempre alquila.
texts.en:
Mrs. Elizabeth Esther is a 38 year old single mother. She graduated from high school but could not continue studying because she had to begin working. She has a 6 year old daughter who is in the first grade of elementary school. They live in the city of Trujillo in Trujillo, La Libertad, Peru. To improve her economic situation, she used to have a small business selling vegetables in the Hermelinda market; however, she had to leave this business 6 years ago in order to take care of her daughter. Now she works in the Maribel market in the mornings selling vegetables, and in the afternoons she sells mazamorra (a local dessert) and washes clothing of neighbors. She has worked for 9 years with the Manuela Ramos movement after a friend invited her to participate in the Successful Women II village bank. She decided to join the bank because she wanted to increase her capital in order to facilitate her business. With her first loan of $175, she purchased vegetables, corn, sugar, rice, milk, etc. With this $175 loan which she will repay in 4 months, she would like to invest in the purchase of vegetables, sugar, raisins, corn, etc. She dreams of having her own vegetable stand since up to now, she has always rented one.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of vegetables and other food items

loans.name: David

texts.en: David A. sells food items like beans, maize and other things at Kissi near Elmina. David has received a Junior High eduaction. He is married and has 6 children, and his wife is a trader. David has been selling food items like beans, maize and others since 2004. He is responsible for paying his children's school fees and other utility bills. His loan will be used to add to her capital to buy more bags of beans and maize to sell. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest into the business to increase sales, which will eventually increase his income.

loans.use: To buy more bags of beans and maize to sell

loans.name: Ann

texts.es: La señora Ann pertenece al Banco Comunal “Corazón de Jesús”, ubicado en el Jr. José del Carmen Cabrejos Nº. 762, distrito de Callería, provincia de Coronel Portillo, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 46 años de edad, es madre de 4 hijos, 2 mayores de edad y 2 que aún dependen de ella, es casada y su esposo se dedica al trabajo de carpintería metálica. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de salchipapa. Tiene 2 años trabajando con el banco comunal.nnEn la actualidad cuenta con un taller de costura en casa. En las mañanas se dedica a su hogar y por las tardes confecciona prendas de vestir para damas, caballeros y niños.nnCon este préstamo de S/1,400, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 6 metros de tela dacrón, 8 kilos de tela algodón, 2 docenas de cierres, hilos y otros.nnGracias a Manuela Ramos su negocio ha crecido y tiene el deseo de seguir progresando en su negocio para la estabilidad de sus hijos. nn
texts.en:
Mrs. Ann belongs to the Community Bank Corazon de Jesus, located on Jr. Josue del Carmen Cabrejos Nuba 762, Callerueda Discrict, province of Colonel Portillo, department of Ucyali. She is 46 years old and is a mother of 4, two grown and 2 who still depend on her. She is married and her house is dedicated to metal carpentry. with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 soles, she decided to invest it in the sale of salchipapa. She has two years working with the community bank. She actually has a sewing workshop in her house. in the mornings she dedicates herself to her home, and in the afternoon to crafting men's, women's, and children's clothes. With this loan of 1400 soles, whish she will repay in 4 months, she will by 6 meters of dacrun fabric, 8 kilos of cotton, 2 dozen buttons, needles, and more. Thanks to Manuela Ramos her business has grown and she hopes to continue progressing in her business for the stability of her children.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth, buttons, needles, etc.

loans.name: Lili

texts.es:
La señora Lili es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Estrellitas II”, vive en el departamento y provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto. Es técnica en Enfermería y por razones ajenas a su voluntad no lo ejerce. Se dedica a la venta de frutas así como anticuchos por las tardes. Su negocio está ubicado en su propia casa ubicado en el Jr. Víctor Belaunde Nº 489. 

Con este préstamo de S/.1,500, el cual será cancelado en 06 meses, comprará frutas como plátanos, papayas, piñas, arroz, azúcar, aceite, carnes, condimentos para la preparación de sus preparados y satisfacer los gustos de sus clientes.

Ella tiene 38 años de edad, vive con su hija quien está estudiando y aún depende de ella. Su meta es poner un negocio de abarrotes y ejercer su carrera.
texts.en:
Lili is a member of the communal bank "Las Estrellitas II", and she lives in the province of San Martin, in the Tarapoto district. She is a nurse but for reasons out of her control she is not working in her field. She sells fruits and anticuchos (a typical Peruvian dish) in the afternoons. Her business is located in her own home in Jr. Victor Belaunde #489. With this S/.1500 loan, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy fruits such as bananas, papayas, pineapples, rice, sugar, oil, meats, and seasonings for her prepared dishes in order to satisfy her customers’ preferences. She is 38 years old and lives with her daughter, who is still studying and depends on her. Lili wants to open her own convenience store and to work in her field.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha Cereceda, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bananas, papayas, pineapples, rice, sugar, oil, and meats, and seasonings.

loans.name: Irshad Gallu Group

texts.en:
My name is Irshad and I am a 43-year-old married lady. I live in Vehari, Pakistan. I own a two-room brick house in which I have lived with my family for the past 30 years. My husband's name is G. and he works as a delivery man. He specifically delivers fruits and vegetables from one place to another. I am a mother of one son whose name is Ramzan. He is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

I have an embroidery business. I make embroidered dresses on order and earn income. I invested some of my income in a committee, and have decided to marry off my son when I receive the committee amount. I successfully repaid my first loan which I took from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying for a loan ($500) to repair my son's auto-rickshaw.

I have some more members in my group. Kosar Baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw. Saima Baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Naseem Baji wants a loan to buy tea and sugar for her tea stall. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw, purchase another rickshaw, scraps, and goods for a tea stall

loans.name: Kear

texts.en: Mrs. Kear Y. is a villager in Phum Thmey village in Kampong Cham province. She is a fruitseller. Her husband, Mr. Tub Sengny, helps his wife at her business. He now wants to be a motorbike taxi driver; unfortunately, he does not have enough money to purchase the motorbike. Thus, Mrs. Kear Y. decided to ask for a loan to help pay for it. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan. She is 23 years old and the mother of two children who are too young to work or study. Her husband is presented on the right in this photo.

loans.use: To help purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: B. Maria is 40 years old and married with 4 children.Maria sells wooden planks. She is a LAPO client and she lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGn ( $350) to purchase more planks to sell. She says thanks to Kiva and all who makes these loans possible.

loans.use: To purchase more wooden planks to sell

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mrs. Phalla K. is 35 and her husband, Mr. Sokha Mao, is 38. They live on an Island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1991 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. All of the children are in school.

Phalla has been a silk weaver for twenty years. It’s a skill she learned from her sister. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who then takes them to sell at market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been selling lottery tickets to villagers in his village for ten years. Phalla is requesting a loan for $350 to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Grace's Group

texts.en:
M. Grace is the leader of Byantuuyo group in Jinja. She is a hard working lady with a hotel/restaurant/bar business that she has been running for over five years and the same premise. She prepares breakfast, lunch and supper and in the evenings, people gather and have a cold beer just to relax from a hard day’s work.

From her businesses, she has been able to pay school fees for her five children, feed them as well as save money. She again needs a loan to be able to buy more food stuffs and drinks for her restaurant and bar.

loans.use: Buy more food stuffs and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 31-year-old Janeth M. from Dar es Salaam. She is single with one child who is six years old. Janeth has been running a beauty salon business since 2005. This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or braided, and made to look like your own.

She works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, six days per week and she is assisted by one employee. Janeth currently earns about US $90 monthly profit from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase hair products. In the future, she plans to open another business. Janeth thanks you for your support!
	
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchase hair products.

loans.name: Kadidia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadidia  D. est âgée  de  44 ans  mère de 5 enfants et vit dans une famille polygame avec son époux, sa coépouse et leurs enfants dans le quartier Sogomougou de la ville de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). N’ayant pas été à l’école pour des raisons sociales, Madame Kadidia D., pour subvenir à ses propres  besoins, s’intéresse très vite  aux activités génératrices de revenus telles le petit commerce il y’a de cela 15 ans. Forte de son expérience, elle est très sollicitée et appréciée à Koutiala. De nos jours Kadidia va beaucoup plus vers la distribution et la vente en gros de l’atiéké (une denrée alimentaire à base de manioc  ou d’igname). 
Dans un souci de satisfaire ses clients et clientes Kadidia a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a 2 ans. Après avoir bouclé un premier prêt avec succès, elle envisage un second prêt individuel pour une durée de 12 mois et d’un montant de 500.000 FCFA.
Avec  ce prêt, elle compte acheter de la  Côte d’Ivoire, un important stock pour le ravitaillement de la plupart des détaillants d’atiéké de la ville de Koutiala. En plus du ravitaillement elle fait la vente en détail à l’intention des consommateurs au grand marché de la ville de Koutiala.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice de 150.000 FCFA qu’elle utilisera pour le remboursement des échéances et l’entretien de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Kadidia D., age 44, is the mother of five children and lives in a polygamous family with her husband, co-wife, and their children in the Sogomougou district of Koutiala City (region of Sikasso). Not having attended school for societal reasons, she soon became interested fifteen years ago in earning an income to support herself through such work as small-scale commerce. Highly experienced, she is appreciated and in much demand in Koutiala. These days, Kadidia is leaning a lot more towards the wholesale distributing and selling of atiéké (a cassava or yam foodstuff).

Concerned about satisfying her customers, Kadidia turned toward the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. After having settled an initial loan successfully, she envisions a second individual loan for a 12-month period in the amount of 500,000 francs CFA. With this loan, she intends to resupply herself with a sizable stock of goods from Cote d’Ivoire mostly for the retailers of atiéké of Koutiala City. In addition to restocking, she sells retail, aimed at consumers at the grand marketplace of Koutiala.

With this loan, she envisions realizing a profit of 150,000 francs CFA that will be used to make loan payments and to care for her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies of "atiéké"

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy N. is 35 years old and married with six children. She has a bookshop where she sells books. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more books to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more books to sell

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La señora Juana, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Vista Alegre”  que esta ubicado en la Comunidad de Queñuani, distrito de Yunguyo, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno.  Ella tiene 55 años de edad,está casada y es madre de 08 hijos,  solo uno sigue estudiando.  Tiene estudios de primaria incompleta (transición), y vive en el Barrio  Río de la plata.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela R. desde hace ya 1 año.  Con su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles compró ovejas. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 500.00 Nuevos soles, para poder invertir en su actual negocio, comprará ovejas.  Paralelamente también tiene un pequeño negocio de venta de sacos de polietileno (plástico).

Su mayor sueño es continuar trabajando.

A ella le gustan los ahorros  y las charlas de capacitación que les da Manuela R..
texts.en:
Mrs. Juana belongs to the “Vista Alegre” community bank located in the Queñuani Community, Yunguyo district, Chucuito Province, Puno Region. She is 55 years old, married and the mother of 8 children. Only one continues studying. She has not completed primary school (transition). She lives in the Río de la Plata neighborhood.

She has worked with the Manuela R. movement for 1 year. She bought sheep with her first loan of 300.00 PEN.

At this time she needs a loan of 500.00 PEN to invest in her current business. She will buy sheep. She also has a small business in parallel selling bags of polyethylene (plastic).

Her biggest dream is to continue working.

She likes the savings and the training talks given by Manuela R..

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheep, bags of polyethylene

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Eugenia A. is from the town of Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Eugenia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Eugenia owns & operates a manicure business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing hairdressing & beauty services to local community members. Eugenia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Eugenia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eugenia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC. Eugenia is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the loan taken out by Eugenia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.es:
Alejandrina es socia del Banco Comunal Compartir, vive en la comunidad de San Martín de Paraíso.
Alejandrina es conviviente, tiene 32 años y dos hijos, Alejandrina junto a su pareja se dedican a la agricultura de verduras como perejil, culantro, sus ventas los realiza en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Alejandrina necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de fertilizantes y semillas.
Los sueños de Alejandrina son mejorar su negocio y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Alejandrina is a member of the Compartir Community Bank. She lives in the community of San Martín de Paraíso. Alejandrina is married, 32 years old and has two children. Together with her husband she farms herbs, such as parsley and coriander, which she sells in the Ayacucho city market. Alejandrina needs a loan in the amount of 2000 soles, which she plans to invest in the purchasing of fertilizers and seeds. She dreams of improving her business and providing her children with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Mariana Hungria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Horn

texts.en: Mrs. Horn P. is a villager in Trapaing Khnol Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who makes a living by growing rice on a small piece of land that she owns. Her husband, Mr. Orm Ton, is a horse-cart driver who can make a little income to support the family. Although they try to work hard, they earn less income than they need to support the family. Thus, Mrs. Horn P. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow to breed. She has two children. One child is a farmer and the other one is studying. Her husband appear on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To o buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
La señora Rosa es socia del Banco Comunal “Central Progreso”, en el distrito de Cuturapi, provincia de Yunguyo, en el departamento de Puno, ella tiene 58 años de edad, de estado civil casada, tiene 7 hijos (5 a su cargo), ella es no letrada, vive en el Sector Flor Kantuta del centro poblado de Chimbo.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 9 años, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, monto con el cual pudo adquirir ganado menor.

Actualmente, ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 3000.00 nuevos soles, este préstamo le servirá para poder adquirir ganado menor (ovinos), además también va a comprar burros los cuales los vende en las ferias de ganado.

Su deseo es continuar trabajando para educar a  sus hijos.

A ella le gustan las reuniones y los ahorros.
texts.en:
Señora Rosa is a member of the community bank “Central Progreso” in the district of Cuturapi, Yunguyo Province, in the department of Puno. She is 58 years of age and married. She has 7 children (5 under her care). She is not educated.. She lives in the Flor Kantuta Sector of the community of Chimbo. Rosa has worked with the Manuela Ramos Movement for 9 years. Her first loan was for 300 new soles, an amount with which she was able to acquire young livestock. Currently she is requesting a loan of 300 new soles. This loan will be used to enable her to acquire young sheep. In addition she is going to buy burros which she sells at livestock markets. Her wish is to continue working in order to educate her children.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of sheep and burros.

loans.name: Luis Alfonso

texts.es: El señor Luís Alfonso R. López , tiene la edad de 55 años , habita en el barrio Los Ríos , ubicado en el municipio de Ticuantepe , junto a su esposa la cual trabaja como comerciante en la venta de carne de  cerdo , para apoyarle con los gastos del hogar , ellos tiene cinco hijos , dos de ellos independiente y los tres estudiantes actualmente , los planes hacia su familia es mejorar las condiciones de vida , don Luís desde hace 22 años se dedica a los trabajos agrícolas,  los planes futuros hacia su cultivo es reforestar y trabajar la tierra en conservación de suelo . Con el préstamo va a comprar fertilizante e insumos y poder mejorar  siembra para poder vender a mejor precio en el mercado. Da las gracias a la institución por los préstamo ya con este seria el noveno el cual ha logrado mejores resultados.
texts.en:
Mr. Luis Alfonsto R. L. is 55 years old and lives with his wife at Los Rios district in the town of Ticuantepe, Nicaragua. His wife works selling pork meat to help with the household expenses. They have five children, two of them are on their own and the three others are currently students. The family wishes to improve their life conditions. Mr. Luis has been a farm worker since he was 22, and plans to reforest and work on his land for soil conservation. He plans on buying fertilizers and improve the seeding, in order to sell his food for a better price in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Chhel

texts.en:
Chhel B., 49, lives in Takeo province where she is a professional clothes decorator. Since 1999, she has been using beads and other materials to make flower designs on women’s clothes to earn a living and typically makes US$4 each day. Her finished work is a kind of Khmer traditional dress and people wear it during Water Festival, P’chum Ben or Khmer New Year.

It takes around 7 to 10 days to complete each dress and its price is expensive, too. Most of the people prefer hand-made rather than machine-made. Chhel said she learned how to decorate from her mother and she started doing this business before she was married.

Chhel’s husband is also a professional handicraft decorator and makes the same amount she does. This couple has six children and three of them are students.

Chhel is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase beads, silk and other materials to expand her business. Her daughter is shown in the photo because Chhel was not available.

loans.use: To buy beads, silk and other materials

loans.name: Secundina Lucila

texts.es: La sra. Lucila tiene su restaurant en la zona D. Pampahasi, lleva ya cuarenta y ocho años con esta actividad, es muy conocida por la zona , su esposo es  rentista y le ayuda a atender el restaurant, sus hijos ya son independientes pero siempre D. preocupan por estar con ellos, es una cliente antigua y muy responsable, el crédito será invertido en la compra D. arroz por quintales y fideo por bolsas, ya que le ofertaron a un precio rebajado, porque para la fiesta D. Todos Santos estos productos tienden a subir D. precio.
texts.en:
Lucila has a restaurant in the Pampahasi region. She has had it for 48 years, and she is very well known in the region. Her husband is an investor, and he helps her take care of the restaurant. Her children are now independent, but they are always on her mind. She is a long time, very responsible client. The loan is to buy rice in “quintales” (one hundred pounds) and bags of noodles. They are now offered at a reduced price. These products tend to rise in price during the Todos Santos festival.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wholesale rice and noodles

loans.name: Adelina

texts.en:
Adelina B. is from the village of Daan Lungrud, Gingoog City. She is 51 years old. Adelina is married and has 10 adult-aged children. To make a living, Adelina owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Adelina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Adelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Adelina is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 12th loan taken out by Adelina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the house. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Felix Alejandro

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Managua, el señor Feliz C. como todo padre responsable y comprometido con el bienestar de sus hijos, se dedica a trabajar fuertemente para llevar el sustento a su casa de habitación.

Actualmente ha solicitado un crédito para contribuir al desarrollo de sus hijos por medio de la compra de una computadora para que ellos puedan estudiar y realizar los trabajos de su colegio. Espera muy confiadamente en que el crédito le servirá de mucho y de esta manera mejorará las condiciones de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
In the town of Managua, Mr. Felix C., as any father, responsible and commited to the well-being of his children, works hard to provide for his family.

Presently Mr. C. has requested a loan to contribute to the development of his children by buying them a computer so they can study and make their homework. He is confident that the loan will serve him well, and this way improve the living conditions of his family.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a computer for his children to study.

loans.name: Sylvie

texts.fr: H. Sylvie est née en 1974 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Sylvie est mariée à AHLONSOU Jacques et est mère de trois enfants dont certains sont scolarisés. Sylvie vit avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Kpankpan à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis neuf ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Sylvie a très tôt abandonné l’école. Il y a six ans de cela que Sylvie mène comme activité, la vente de comprimés, des pâtes dentifrice et des brosses à dent à son domicile. Sylvie s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Sylvie sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et agrandir son commerce.
texts.en:
H. Sylvie was born in 1974 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  She is married to AHLONSOU Jacques and is the mother of three children, some of whom are in school.  She has been living with her husband and children for nine years in the Kpankpan district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  The couple provides for the family jointly  Very early on, Sylvie dropped out of school.  For six years, she has been selling pills, toothpaste, and toothbrushes out of her home.  She supplies herself from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans.  She's requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé to augment her working capital and to expand her business. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tablets, toothpaste, and toothbrushes

loans.name: Dulamsuren

texts.en:
O. Dulamsuren is 52 years old and lives with her husband in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her husband live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. She operates a dairy products trading business in her town. She purchases dairy products locally from herders in the surrounding countryside, and transports them back to her town to sell. 

Dulamsuren started her business in 2008, after previously managing several different businesses over the years. She has worked hard and has built a stable operation over the last two years. She attributes her success to her good accounting skills and reasonable prices. Dulamsuren is looking toward the future and says, "I hope to expand my business and own my own shop in the future." She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan to increase her inventory so that she has plenty to sell when supplies get short this winter.


About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All&sectors[]=All&regions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda E. is from the village of Estrada. She is 49 years old. Imelda is married and has three school-aged children. 

To make a living, Imelda runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of products in the local community. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2006, Imelda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Imelda is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering.

loans.name: Sope Serigne Babacar Sy Group No. 14

texts.en:
Sope Serigne Babacar Sy is an association of female commercantes (vendors) working in Thies, a city about seventy kilometers from Dakar.

The association, named after an important marabout (a religious leader in West African Islam), was founded in 2006 by a group of entrepreneurial women from the Cité Lamy neighborhood. Their aim was to help the members finance their small businesses through a revolving savings fund called a tontine, in which members contribute a small amount to the pot each month to finance one member's activities.

Today, the association has evolved to secure group loans for its members through cooperation with UIMCEC (Union of Institution Mutualiste Communautaire d’Epargne et de Credit). Groups of five are financed through ten-month loans of which each member receives an equal amount. On the 20th of each month, the members of the association hold a meeting to collect the repayments.

Currently, there are fourteen groups of women financed through UIMCEC. Sope Serigne Babacar Sy is headed by Ms. Coumba Faye, the president, and Ms. Oumu Ngom, the treasurer.

Ms. Fatou G. is the head of Group No. 14. She, like many of the women, has a small stall in the market of Grand Thies, one of the bigger neighborhoods of Thies. She sells sandwiches, starting around 7 a.m. and often finishing around midnight. She says her specialty is a beef sandwich with fried onions. If she has the money, Ms. G. also buys handbags and bras to sell in the market. Ms. G. is married, and the mother of seven children.

Three of the other group members also work in the Grand Thies market: Ms. Amy N. runs a small restaurant, serving rice dishes, such as thiébu dieune (rice and fish); Ms. Fatou N. sells guedia (dried fish); and Ms. Ndeye Marième Djité sells women's clothing, mostly pants. The final group member, Ms. Adama N., sells vegetables and fish out of her home. Each member receives 100,000 FCFA to bolster their activities.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: B. Jeanne est née en 1963 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Jeanne s’est installée à Yénawa, un quartier de Cotonou, depuis 15 ans environs. Jeanne est mariée à HOUNSOU Nicolas et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Yénawa. Jeanne vient en aide à son mari, en ce qui concerne l’entretien et l’éducation des enfants, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. En effet, Jeanne n’a pas fréquenté l’école, mais vend depuis une dizaine d’année, des boissons en cannettes dans sa boutique. Jeanne s’approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois crédits auprès de l’institution. Jeanne a bien remboursé  ces trois crédits. Jeanne envisage augmenter le stock de ses produits et diversifier son activité par la vente de divers autres produits ; ce qui lui permettra de mieux satisfaire les demandes de ses clients. Mais compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose, Jeanne sollicite un quatrième crédit pour agrandir son activité.
texts.en:
B. Jeanne was born in 1963 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She became situated in Yénawa, a district of Cotonou, about fifteen years ago. She is married to HOUNSOU Nicolas and is the mother of two children, who are both in school. The family lives together in Yénawa. Thanks to the revenues she earns from her business, Jeanne works in aid of her husband where it concerns maintaining the children's education. Basically, Jeanne did not attend school, but she has been selling canned drinks in her store for ten years. She stocks up in Lomé, Togo, a country neighboring Benin. She is a previous client of ALIDé having already obtained three loans from it. She has repaid these three loans. Jeanne envisions increasing her inventory of goods and diversifying her business by selling a variety of other products. This will enable her to do better in satisfying the demands of her customers. But due to few financial means available to her, she is requesting a fourth loan to expand her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying canned drinks

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
la señóra Juana F. tiene 55 años de edad, esta casada y tiene 9 hijos los cuales 3 hijos que dependen de ella y 6 que se encuentran en los ee.uu.
el esposo se dedica al corte de caña en la temporada y es agricultor.
Juana se dedica al comercio vende granos basicos y refrescos, esta solicitando el credito para comprar mas mercaderia y tener mayor inventario en su negocio.
texts.en:
Juana F., 55, is married and has 9 children, 3 of whom are still dependent on her and 6, who are in the United States. Her husband is a farmer and works as a seasonal sugar cane cutter. Juana sells basic grains and beverages. She is asking for funding to buy merchandise so that she can have a larger inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita G. is from the village of Brgy. Lactawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 55 years old. Merlita is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Merlita owns and operates a business providing tailoring services to local community members. Merlita has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Merlita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. Merlita is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and thread. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Merlita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and thread

loans.name: Lith Angelica

texts.es:
La Sra. Lith Angélica, es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Orquídeas”, del Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia y Departamento de San Martín. Es casada tiene 27 años y 01 hijo que aun depende de ella.
Lith se dedica a la confección de prendas de vestir y a la compra y venta de cacao. Se encuentra ubicado en su propia casa y el negocio de venta de granos lo realiza en el Distrito Pucacaca, que es uno de los pueblos donde se cosecha en gran cantidad este producto y luego lo vende a la planta de chocolates.
Con este préstamo de S/. 2,500.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará Telas de diferentes colores y tamaños, hilos de diferentes colores, para confeccionar y luego vender en los  pueblos aledaños. Y parte del dinero lo invertirá en cacao.
Lith Angélica se siente llena de vida y con ganas de seguir adelante, su sueño es tener un Taller de costura grande muy bien acondicionado y al mismo tiempo también agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  en iniciar su negocio
texts.en:
La Sra. Lith Angélica, es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Orquídeas”, del Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia y Departamento de San Martín. Es casada tiene 27 años y 01 hijo que aun depende de ella. Lith se dedica a la confección de prendas de vestir y a la compra y venta de cacao. Se encuentra ubicado en su propia casa y el negocio de venta de granos lo realiza en el Distrito Pucacaca, que es uno de los pueblos donde se cosecha en gran cantidad este producto y luego lo vende a la planta de chocolates. Con este préstamo de S/. 2,500.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará Telas de diferentes colores y tamaños, hilos de diferentes colores, para confeccionar y luego vender en los pueblos aledaños. Y parte del dinero lo invertirá en cacao. Lith Angélica se siente llena de vida y con ganas de seguir adelante, su sueño es tener un Taller de costura grande muy bien acondicionado y al mismo tiempo también agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir en iniciar su negocio

Translated from Spanish by Alex Jaffe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprarà telas en  metros , hilos de diferentes colores para surtir su negocio.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
Yolanda tiene 42 años, es casada y tiene 4 hijos en edad escolar. Vive en la localidad de “Quimbiri”, ubicada en la selva cuzqueña, donde tienen su casa propia.

Anteriormente se dedicaba a la actividad agrícola, pero como no lo estaba dando buenos  resultados incursionó en la venta de comida (brochetas de corazón de res y postres) en su barrio. En esta actividad ya lleva 15 años y trabaja arduamente desde las 4 de la tarde hasta las 11 de la noche, contando con la ayuda de sus hijos en el tiempo de vacaciones escolares (enero y febrero). No satisfecha con ello, se propone abrir en un futuro cercano, una tienda donde venda galletas, gaseosas, golosinas, etc., con el propósito de obtener mayores ganancias y clientes.

Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP y se compromete a cumplir con sus pagos en las fechas oportunas; también agradece a su banco comunal por las facilidades que le otorgan cuando existe cualquier eventualidad económica.

Con el dinero solicitado invertirá en la implementación del local para su futura tienda y en la compra de los ingredientes para sus comidas.
texts.en:
Yolanda, 42, is married and has 4 school-aged children. She lives in the town of “Quimbiri," located in the Cuzqueñan forest, where she has her own house. Previously she worked in agriculture, but as this was not giving her good results she entered into the business of selling food (skewers of beef heart and pastries) in her neighborhood. She has been carrying out this activity for 15 years, and she works tirelessly from 4 in the afternoon until 11 at night. Her children help her during the months of school vacation (January and February). Not satisfied with just this activity, she is proposing to open a store in the near future where she will sell cookies, soft drinks, sweets, etc., with the objective of having a greater number of customers and higher earnings. This is her 3rd loan with MFP, and she is committed to making her payments at the scheduled times. In addition she is grateful to her communal bank for giving her the opportunity to borrow at reasonable terms at times when she needs the money. With the money requested she will invest in the installation of a site for her future store, and will also purchase ingredients for her meals.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her meals

loans.name: Nain

texts.en:
Nain Christina is a married mother of eight who currently lives in Kikfuini, Cameroon. Christina is requesting her second loan from GHAPE. She has been with GHAPE since 2008 and has demonstrated a credit-worthy character exemplified by her repayments, consistent attendance at meetings, and support of her borrowing group. 

With this latest loan, Christina is hoping to continue the business practices supported by her prior loans. She has requested 110,000 CFA in order to purchase two goats, two piglets, and bags of feed. The rest will be put towards clearing and hoeing of her farm. She believes her business will succeed because of her prior experience. She has been in this business for over ten years. She hopes to use the profits from her business to continue reinvesting in her business, purchase kitchen utensils, pay for her children’s textbooks and meet her GHAPE obligations. Her biggest struggle has been the passing of her two sisters within a year. It is a burden she lives with everyday and will do what is necessary to ensure her children stay healthy and safe.   

Christina’s loan will be provided through the Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE), a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy goats, piglets and seedlings

loans.name: Blanca Rosa

texts.es: La señora Blanca Rosa es madre de 2 pequeñas niñas pues hace tiempo su esposo falleció y quedo viuda. Pero a pesar del dolor que paso ella sigua adelante para ofrecer una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijas. Ella tiene una papelería y mercería llamada “Angelique” desde hace 2 años. Blanca ofrece a sus clientes variedad de artículos escolares a un bajo precio, pero en este momento requiere de un préstamo para poder surtir su negocio y así obtener mayor ganancias.
texts.en:
Ms. Blanca Rosa is the mother of two small daughters who she raises alone after her husband passed away some time ago. Despite the pain that she endured from his death, she works to move forward and offer a better quality of life for her daughters. She has owned a stationary and hardware store called “Angelique” for the past two years. Blanca offers her customers a variety of merchandise at a low price, but currently needs a loan to buy more supplies for her business so that she can earn bigger profits.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Heyd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for business

loans.name: Héctor

texts.en:
Héctor O., a 47-year-old native of the city of Roque González, has been married for 23 years to Petrona Fleitas, who is 50 years old. They have five children; their two youngest are in school and their three oldest are professionals. 

Twenty years ago with help from Petrona, Héctor started his own small store in his home. At the same time he was studying to finish his teaching degree. Now, aside from his business, Hector receives a wage that helps him attain a higher household income.

Thanks to the great location of his business, his store is usually very busy with customers. He would like more capital to buy more products so that he can satisfy the needs of his clientele. He came to Fundacion Paraguaya  to ask for a loan so he can buy flour, rice, noodles, bread products, dairy products, meat and other necessary products.

loans.use: to buy flour, rice, noodles, bread products, dairy products, meat and other necessary products

loans.name: Fuente De Bendicion 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Jose is the coordinator of his group, Fuente D. Bendicion (Source of Blessing), and his story is representative of his group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti). His group is located in Puerto Plata, a port town on the north coast, where the economy is dependent on tourism and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. He makes his home here in a simple structure with his children.
Jose is excited to be taking his first loan with Kiva partner, Esperanza, after being denied access to credit from other sources. He plans to use this loan to invest in his business making cleaning products by purchasing the chemicals he needs to produce his cleaning products. He will use the profits to feed his children. His long-term goal is to grow his business and add more products. He thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals to produce cleaning products

loans.name: Gantugs

texts.en: Gantugs J. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and son in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Gantugs and his wife operate an agriculture business in their town. They began their business early in 2010 and since then, they have been able to rent a plot of land for two years where they operate agriculture with some friends as a group. They have begun this business based on the experience of working on World Vision Organization's training, which enabled them to plant vegetables and other plants grown for food. Gantugs wants to keep expanding the amounts and types of vegetables under the supervision of an experienced trainer in the group. Gantugs is a neat, hardworking and straight person. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a large amount of fertilizer and composting soil, watering equipment and seed for his business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, compost, seeds and equipment

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en: Marlene T. is a 45-year-old married woman who lives in Sto. Canonoy, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by engaging in fishing and fish vending. Marlene’s 50-year-old husband, Jose Jolito, is a fisherman and they have six children who are between 18 and 27 years old. Some of their children are already working in order to help them in defraying family and other expenses. Marlene joined NWTF-Project Dungganon (NWTF-PD) in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a fishing and fish-vending business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 12,000 from her business activities. Marlene is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 18,000 was used to fund operations of her fishing and fish-vending business and it had a positive impact on both the business and on the family’s living conditions. Now, Marlene is borrowing Php 8,000 for her 16th loan which she intends to use for her fishing and fish-vending business. She is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her fishing and fish-vending business

loans.name: Jinja Central B-Jinja Group

texts.en:
Looking at somebody’s end of month balance sheets can give you a fair or relative idea of how well their business is doing. If you take the example of 38-year-old divorced N. Florence, a shoe seller for seven years now, you will be brought to terms with her variable business prospects.

In a week, this diligent lady makes about $67, and in a month she gets approximately $266. This is notwithstanding the operational cost challenges of running a business. Her shoe selling business profits have permitted her to shoulder most of her family’s financial requirements. 

All of her four buoyant children are happily in school. She has also been eking side profits from another lucrative business - raising poultry. With this loan, she wants to purchase more pairs of shoes that she will later resell to her increasing clientele. She envisages a situation where she will be able to see her balance sheet triple what she is making now.

loans.use: The purchase of more shoes to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy stock items for her store (rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, etc.)

loans.name: José Ángel

texts.es:
José Ángel R.  y su esposa quieren dar a su único hijo un patrimonio con el cual en un futuro se pueda defender. Ellos cuentan con una vivienda que con ahorros fueron construyendo poco a poco; en la cual ahora desean construir una recamara mas para vivir cómodamente y dar a su hijo su propio espacio para cuando el crezca. 
José trabaja como almacenista en una maquiladora y su esposa para apoyarlo se dedica a la cuenta de ropa usada.
texts.en:
José Ángel R. and his wife want to give their only child assets with which he can make his way in the future. They have a house which they built little by little with savings. They want to build one more bedroom to live more comfortably and give their son more space for when he grows. Jose is a warehouse worker in a factory and his wife sells used clothing to help him.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok Y. is a 67-year-old farmer who lives in Kompong Tom Province. Sok Y. is married to Mr. Ou Ken, age 71, who works with her in the farming business. Sok Y. owns a plot of farmland that she uses to plant crops. Growing crops is business with which she has had great success. She is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. Sok Y. is concerned that she currently lives in an old house which needs repair. As she doesn’t have money to repair and replace the broken parts of her house, Sok Y. decided to pursue a loan from Kiva’s project partner, HKL.

loans.use: To repair and replace a section of her house.

loans.name: Nelida

texts.es: Nélida tiene 28 años, vive en su casa propia con su esposo y sus 3 hijos. Esta luchadora mujer se dedica a sembrar maíz, desde que era muy joven aprendió las técnicas  que le enseñaron sus padres y hermanos. Cada día se despierta con el alba para dirigirse hacía sus campos agrícolas, para vigilar y cuidar que la plaga de insectos o el mal tiempo dañe el desarrollo de sus plantaciones. Aunque es un trabajo algo duro para una mujer, dice que le gusta mucho ya que la motiva el hecho de sacar adelante a sus hijos, y cuando es tiempo de cosechar vende muy bien toda su producción, y con el dinero que obtiene, puede dar el sustento y educación a sus hijos. Para el futuro tiene planeado sembrar en mayor cantidad el maíz y contratar los servicios de peones o personal, para obtener mayores ganancias. Es su tercer crédito con MFP, esta muy contenta de  saber que tiene un apoyo financiero ya que siempre ha demostrado  ser responsable en sus pagos, además  le agrada ser parte de su banco comunal porque  todos sus integrantes son personas responsables y muy solidarias, agradece  aquellas personas que serán gestoras del préstamo que solicita y le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá para comprar sacos de abono ya que esta en plena temporada de siembra.
texts.en:
Nelida is 28 years old and lives in her own house with her husband and their 3 children. This struggling woman sows corn. When she was very young she learned the technique, taught by her parents and brothers. Each day she gets up at sunrise to head to her agricultural fields to watch out for plagues of insects or bad weather that may harm the development of her crops. Although it is very hard work for a woman, Nelida says that she likes it very much and she's motivated by the desire to advance her children. At harvest time, her produce sells very well, and with the money she receives, she can provide support and education for her children. In the future, she plans to sow a larger quantity of corn and contract the services of day laborers to obtain better earnings. This is Nelida's 3rd loan with MFP. She is very content to know she has this financial help. Nelida has always been very responsible with her payments and is pleased to be part of a communal bank, because all the members are responsible and very supportive people. Nelida also wishes to thank everyone who supports her loan, which will be very useful in her business's progress. With this loan she will buy sacks of manure for we are now in the heart of planting season.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING SACKS OF MANURE TO FERTILIZE HER CORN FIELDS

loans.name: Marivel

texts.en:
Marivel M. is from the village of Pinmulaan, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 31 years old. Marivel is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $175 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marivel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, meat, fish, cooking oil, seasoning, peppers etc.

loans.name: Keji

texts.en: Keji M. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell. Keji is 35 years old and married; her husband also works. She has 7 children who all attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: to stock more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell

loans.name: Teolijean

texts.en:
Teolijean L., from the village of Hinigdaan, El Salvador City, Misamis Oriental, is 26 years old and married. To make a living, Teolijean owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily-use products such as pollard, rice and corn bran and also retails gasoline per liter in the local community. Additionally, she operates a retail store selling snack foods and breads. Teolijean has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Teolijean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional products to buy and sell, she is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP to use as working capital and to purchase additional inventory for sale. This will be Teolijean's fourth loan from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Working capital and to purchase additional inventory for sale

loans.name: George Kihara

texts.en: George has practised farming in the town of Njabini for the last 20 years. He is 57 years old and takes care of his eight children after divorcing his wife. George was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He plans to use the cash to start a business selling bedsheets, blankets and bedcovers. In the future, George hopes to diversify to other fields and have many businesses in Njabini.

loans.use: to start a business selling bedsheets, blankets and bedcovers.

loans.name: Tursunoi's Group

texts.en:
The Southern part of Kyrgyzstan is proud to have rich land for cultivating many crops. Agriculture is so important in the economy of the country that even the national emblem displays wheat and cotton, known as “white gold”.  Along with wheat and cotton, other cultivations are being developed such as vegetables, fruits, and grains.

Tursunoi N., 53, is the leader of this group. She has been active in farming for fourteen years. At this moment she’s getting ready to prepare land to plant potato seeds.  Tursunoi started the farming business fourteen years ago with wheat cultivation on land that she possessed after the privatization. She invested 890 soms into her business start-up, which was a rather significant amount at that time. Now she earns an income of 3900 soms every month. She hopes to obtain this loan to purchase fertilizers and potato seeds. Tursunoi’s sons are in Russia at this moment, and promise to assist her financially so that she will be able to repay this loan. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
