Catalina makes a living by selling ornamental plants. She grows garden plants that are native to the Philippines, like ylang-ylang, golden shower, and dahlias, and also a variety of hanging plants and others. Her regular customers are local tourists, neighbors and the nearby community. She’s been 22 years in this business, and she earns a minimum of Php 350 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is applying for a loan of Php 25,000. She will be using the money to buy things needed for planting, such as fertilizer, pots, seedlings, plastics and wires. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Catalina hopes her business grows in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for gardening materials and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Tautala

texts.en:
Tautala is 52 years old, married and has 5 children

Tautala owns & operates a business, planting & harvesting taro for sale. She has many years experience in this business. Tautala needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Tautala joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Tautala's 2nd loan with SPBD. 



*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the ""overall social metric score.""  For example, a 3 out of 3 on ""level of education"" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Jorena

texts.en: Jorena, a 39-year-old married mother of seven children, lives in the Philippines where she has operated a shop that sells soaps, detergents and shampoo for the past five years. A member of HSPFI since 2011, she is requesting a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy more soaps, detergents and shampoo. In the future, Jorena hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy soaps, detergents & shampoo.

loans.name: Cristita

texts.en:
Cristita is 59 years old, married, and has two children.

Cristita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a variety store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Cristita has borrowed and paid 7 loans from NWTF prior to this loan. She has been running the variety store for 6 years and also earns an income from raising pigs.

Cristita aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is sixty four years old and a widow with six children. She has owned a business selling general farm supplies and equipment to local farmers for  two years. Naomi needs a loan of WST $1,500 to purchase general agricultural supplies and equipment. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 200 talas or US $83 per week) to improve and expand the business.

In 2010, Naomi joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral. This is Naomi's second loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase general agricultural supplies and equipment

loans.name: Good Time Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 59-year-old Alice from Mutare. She is married and is living with one child, who is attending school. She also cares for two dependents.

Alice runs a retail business selling electrical gadgets (fridges, tvs and radios) and clothes. The business has been in operation for 8 years. She says the main challenges faced are high customs duties at the border post.

Alice has requested a loan of $900 to purchase electrical gadgets. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve her family's general welfare. In the future,  Alice plans to have ownership of her own shop.

loans.use: to buy clothes from South Africa for resale

loans.name: Singam Diom Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de crédit Singam Diom est le nom d’une association de femmes habitant cote à cote dans le même village. Après avoir bien réfléchi à l’idée d’appuyer leur mari dans les charges de la maison, ces femmes se sont regroupées  afin de pouvoir bénéficier de crédit pour pouvoir s’activer dans le petit commerce. Elles sont au nombre de six et sont ici représentées par trois d’entre elles dont la présidente qui est reconnue comme tenant des épis de mil. 
Elle s’appelle Oumy, elle a 35 ans, mariée et mère d’une fille de 9 ans. Madame Oumy, est récemment entré dans le commerce avec la vente de poisson séché et d’autres variétés de fruits de mer. Elle a démarré avec un capital de 100.000FCFA constitué à partir de ses économies. Elle n’a pas de charges et ses bénéfices sont refinancés dans l’activité.
Elle désire agrandir son commerce un jour.
texts.en:
The loan group Singam Diom is an association of women who live next to one another in the same village. After thinking hard about supporting their husbands with the household expenses, the women joined forces so that they could take advantage of a loan and get involved in a small business.

They are a group of six, and are represented here by three of the women. The president is the one holding ears of millet.

Her name is Oumy. She is 35 years old, married, and the mother of a nine-year-old daughter. Madame Oumy recently went into business by selling dried fish and other types of seafood. She started with 100,000 FCFA from her savings. She does not have expenses, and her profits are put back into her business. One day, she would like to grow her business.

loans.use: buy dried fish and other seafood for resale.

loans.name: Nellly

texts.en:
Nelly is a marvelous, good-hearted young woman who makes her living by practicing mixed farming. She is ambitious and full of hope for the future. 

She makes a living doing mixed farming in the Nandihills area of Kenya. She keeps dairy cows and poultry for commercial milk and eggs, respectively. Besides mixed farming, Nelly is also very concerned about the health of the environment. She spends most of her time working on her farm. 

Nelly is seeking a KES 40,000 loan to purchase cereals. Her village has seen an increase in demand for cereal that is maize and beans and Nelly having an entrepreneurial mind wants to take advantage of that.
The increase in income from the cereal selling business will go to her family's welfare and her children's education. All that remains is for her to say "thank you" to the people who are supporting her project.

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
During her younger days, Myrna learned farming activities because her parents source of livelihood derived from their farm.Until she got married and had children,farming is also their main livelihood.

She availed loan to finance the expenses for her rice production and other farming needs.Myrna hopes to have a good harvest.Her future plan was to save money for the education of her children.

loans.use: To finance the expenses for her rice production and other farming needs

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana has about 18 years of experience in the business of retail. Currently she sells all types of beverages including soda and beer. She also has a pool table where local members of the community come to play. This business was owned by her late husband who passed away two years ago. She has had to take on the work in order to find a way to make ends meet. Her two sons help her at the business as well.

Mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. For more information about microfinance, Ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

loans.use: Invest in products to sell

loans.name: Titin

texts.en: T. is a 28 year-old mother with three children ages 10, 6 and 3. The first two are girls and the last one is a boy. T. makes and sells an Indonesian salad called “gado-gado”. She used to sell gado-gado using just a table, but now owns a small bamboo stall. Her husband passed away 4 years ago, and now she is the only breadwinner for herself and her children. She is raising three kids on her own, and would like to help pay for their college from the business's income.  She really wants greatly expand her business and earn more income for her children’s education.

loans.use: Help expand business of selling an Indonesian salad called gado-gado.

loans.name: Praxides

texts.en:
Praxides is married with four children who are all in primary school. She is a trained tailor. She also operates a small shop to supplement her tailoring business. From both her businesses she is able to meet her family’s basic needs.

In addition to carrying out her businesses, Praxides is also employed in a local clothing shop where she trains students in clothes design and tailoring. Given the loan of $75 from PEMCI, Praxides intends to expand her tailoring shop and also to start her own training facility. She is a lady who is trying her best to empower herself financially and to support her young family.

loans.use: Expand her tailor shop and start a training facility for tailoring

loans.name: Mannelle

texts.en:
This 37-year-old mother of three, Mannelle J. is the proud owner of a small grocery service in Trou-Du-Nord, Haiti. Mannelle’s business is a critical source of income for her three children, Michi (age 4), Nehemio (age 3), and Judelin (age 2), since it is a necessary supplement to her husband's, Antoine, work. With this first loan, she will expand the inventory of her store with essentials such as rice, coffee, and sugar to better meet the needs of her customers.

Note: Mannelle is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $750 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of this loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: Expand the inventory of her store with essentials such as rice, coffee, and sugar.

loans.name: Nicia Figueora

texts.en: Nicia is 26 years old and lives in the town of Guanuma with her beautiful 5-year-old daughter.  Her husband lives and works in another part of the country for a company that sells chickens wholesale. In order to help her family pay for the cost of housing, she wants to start a small business selling clothes and other items to women, such as bed sheets, bed spreads and window curtains. She plans to sell her goods in the capital, Santo Domingo, and acquire them in Elías Piña, a frontier town near the Hatiian border where products can be purchased cheaply.  To meet these goals, she needs a loan of $250 to acquire goods to sell. She will repay her loan over a period of six months.

loans.use: To start a small business selling clothes

loans.name: Leocadia Lola

texts.es:
Mrs. Leocadia is part of the Communcal Bank Manuela Ramos of Tinco, and is dedicated to selling flowers. She began this shop selling flowers in Huaraz, and expanded it with more varieties of flowers, which led to her traveling to Lima for more sales. Today she has stores in the city of Huaraz, the Department of Ancash and another one in Lima. She takes flowers from Huaraz to Lima and while there, purchases other varieties of flowers that she then sells in Huaraz.

With the recent loan awared by Manueal Ramos of S/. 2,500.00, which will be repaid over 6 months, she purchased dozens of flowers of many varietes in order to sell them during the month of november in the fiesta of "Todos los Santos" (All Saints Day).

Her dream is to have her own space in Huaraz or in Lima, in order for her to be able to be more established and travel less.

She is 48 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her profits allow her to support her husband in educating their children. Two of her children are at the University in Lima, one is in Carhuaz and is a technician in a hospital, and the other one has an incurable disease. Mr. Leocadia has resigned herself to taking care of him and continues to work in order to provide more for her sick son.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Leocadia, pertenece al Banco Comunal Manuela Ramos de Tinco, se dedica a la venta de flores, inició su negocio vendiendo flores en Huaraz, fue ampliando su negocio con mas variedades y comenzó a viajar a la ciudad de Lima, ahora tiene dos puestos en la ciudad de Huaraz, Departamento de Ancash y otro en Lima. Lleva flores de Huaraz a Lima y estando allí compra otras variedades de flores y las vende en las florerías de Huaraz. Con el reciente préstamo otorgado por Manuela Ramos de S/. 2,500.00 el cual será cancelado en 6 cuotas, ha comprado flores por docenas de las diferentes variedades para venderlas en el mes de noviembre en la fiesta de “Todos los Santos”. Su deseo es tener un local propio en Huaraz o en Lima, para que pueda tener mayor estabilidad y viajar menos. Ella tiene 48 años, está casada y tiene 4 hijos. Sus ingresos le permite apoyar a su esposo en la educación de sus hijos. Dos de ellos están en la Universidad en Lima, una está en Carhuaz y es Técnica en enfermería y el otro tiene una enfermedad incurable, la señora Leocadia se ha resignado a ello y seguirá trabajando para apoyar mas a su hijo enfermo.

loans.use: Purchase many more flowers

loans.name: Itaifafo

texts.en: Itaifafo is 39 years old, married and has five children. She is an excellent fisherwoman who heads out to sea three days a week -- every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday.  She earns $48 a day from this business, thanks to her own hard work and help from her husband. She and her husband also run a plantation, where they earn an additional $72 a week for themselves and their family.  Itaifafo has applied for a new loan which she will use to buy more fishing gear and renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy fishing gear and for home improvements

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Norma is a happy worker running a warehouse covering a large territory in her community. At the root of her financial problems is that her business failed and had to close it down temporarily. Nevertheless she has not lost hope of restarting her warehouse and making ti the best in her community once again. Due to the lack of capital funds to restock her small warehouse, fo now she works as a farm laborer and sells a few consumer items that she has in her warehouse, just so that her little ones may not have to leave school. With this wish in mind she requests your noble and generous help from her heart, in the form of a sum of money as a loan with the intention to invest it in the purchase of better and larger quantities of products. With these she will once again win the place she once had in her community and by these means help raise her family's standard of living. Only with your help this will be possible.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

NORMA, una alegre bodeguera que hasta hace un tiempo tenia una gran cobertura en su comunidad, a raíz de sus problemas económicos su negocio quebró y tuvieron que cerrarlo momentáneamente; sin embargo ella no pierde la esperanza de hacer de su bodega la mejor de su comunidad una vez más.Debido a la falta de capital para reflotar su pequeña bodega por ahora se dedica a la labor agrícola y a vender los pocos productos de consumo que tiene en su bodega para evitar que sus pequeños hijos abandonen la escuela.Con este deseo en mente solicita la ayuda de vuestro noble y bondadoso corazón con una suma de dinero en calidad de préstamo a fin de invertirlo en la compra de mayor y mejor calidad de productos para poseer una vez la aceptación de su comunidad y por ende elevar su nivel de vida familiar.Solo con su apoyo lo podrá lograr.

loans.use: Investment of capital funds to acquire better and greater quantities of products to restock her small warehouse.

loans.name: Please Delete Group

texts.en: Leonia is a single woman. She has timber business.She want to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand he business.

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es:
Manuel is a young farmer and driver. While he is away at his transportation job for long periods of time, his wife takes care of the land. This business provides for the care and development of their small children. Your support will help improve the quality of their products, and allow them to invest in their business.

MANUEL, es un joven agricultor y transportista, durante sus largos periodos de ausencia su querida esposa se dedica al cuidado y siembra de sus tierras de cultivo debido a que esta actividad es una de las que mejores réditos les proporciona para el normal desarrollo de sus dos pequeñas niñas.Tu aporte contribuirá a mejorar la calidad de sus productos e incrementará su número con la compra de bueyes luego de tu importante aporte.

loans.use: TO INVEST IN HIS FARMING BUSINESS WHICH SUPPORTS HIS WIFE AND TWO YOUNG CHILDREN.

loans.name: Mwanaasha's Mandingo Group

texts.en:
Mwanaasha is 35 years old and is married with 4 children, ages 18, 13, 9, and 3. Mwanaasha is a coal seller; she started her business in 1996. Every day she works from 6:15 AM to 9:30 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more coal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Halima, who has a business dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more coal for her business

loans.name: Marsida

texts.id:
Everyday, Marsida trades various cakes around Suwung Denpasar. She rides a motorcycle to sell the cakes door-to-door. She uses the revenue of the sales as the capital to trade cakes the next day, while the excess is used to fulfill her family’s daily needs. She is expecting more capital to enlarge the business.

Together with her family, Marsida is now living in a rented room in Jl. Mertasari Denpasar.

Translated from Indonesian by Hestyana, Kiva Volunteer.

Usaha sehari-hari yang dijalani oleh Marsida adalah sebagai penjual kue di sekitar Suwung Denpasar. Dia harus berkeliling menggunakan sepeda motornya untuk menjajakan kuenya dari rumah ke rumah. Keuntungan yang didapat kadang dipakai sebagai modal untuk berjualan lagi, sisanya untuk kebutuhan rumah tangga. Saat ini dia sangat mengharapkan bantuan modal untuk mengembangkan usaha jualan kuenya. Bersama keluarganya, Marsida saat ini tinggal dengan menyewa kamar di Jl.Mertasari Denpasar.

loans.use: Increase capital

loans.name: Lydia Floridalma

texts.es:
Lydia Floridalma A. C. resides in the municipality of Cantón Cojxac in the state of Totonicapán. She is the mother of five children. She married when she was 17 years old and back then worked making huipils (typical Mayan embroidered blouses) but left that to join her husband in his work that consists of making furniture (wardrobes, chairs, china cabinets and beds). As a help to him she sells the furniture in the local market of Totonicapán where the business is in great demand.

The loan that she is requesting from ASDIR will serve to increase business capital because, with the help of her children, they will be able to distribute in different parts of the city and in other towns.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Lydia Floridalma A. C. quien con residencia en el Cantón Cojxac, municipio y departamento de Totonicapán. Es madre de cinco hijos. Contrajo matrimonio cuando tenía 17 años, en ese entonces se dedicaba a la costura (elaboración de Güipiles Típicos) pero dejó su trabajo y se dedico al de su esposo el cual consiste en la fabricación de muebles (roperos, sillas, Chineros y camas) como una ayuda a su esposo ella los vende en el mercado local de Totonicapán, el cual tiene mucha demanda este negocio, el crédito que solicita en ASDIR le servirá para el aumento de capital en el negocio ya que con la ayuda de sus hijos podrán distribuirse en diferentes puntos de la ciudad y en otros pueblos circunvecinos.

loans.use: Increase business capital to improve distribution (furniture sales)

loans.name: Donald Cristian

texts.es:
Don Donald is 51 years old and libes in the El Riguero neighborhood. He is married and has two children of schooling age. He would like to be able to support them until they have finished their studies.

Don Donald has a general store in his home, generally sales are good but there are days when sales are very low. Don Donald has eight years of experience doing business with these highs and lows; he began his business with his own savings from a liquidation of his previous job.

His plans are to increase his inventory in order to better attract the attention of his clients. The loan he is soliciting will be used to purchase basic everyday products for his general store.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Don Donald tiene 51 años de edad, habita en el barrio El Riguero, es casado y tiene 2 hijos en edad escolar. Y desea poder apoyarlos siempre hasta que éstos terminen sus estudios. Don Donald tiene una pulpería en su casa de habitación, generlamente las ventas son buenas pero hay días que la ventas son muy bajas y en éstas subidas y bajadas Don Donal tiene 8 años de experiencia en el negocio el cual empezó con fondos propios con dinero producto de una liquidación de su anterior trabajo. Sus planes son poder aumentar el inventario para así mejorar la atención a sus clientes, el crédito solcitado será invertido en la compra de productos de consumo básico para su pulpería.

loans.use: Purchase products of basic consumption

loans.name: Jalal

texts.en: JalA., 22 years old and single, lives in a small village close to Tyre, in the South of Lebanon. JalA. is an electricA. technician for cars. His ambition and willpower led him to request a loan for the first time from A. Majmoua [Kiva’s Field Partner].  He is asking for USD 1,000 to do some maintenance on his shop and to purchase more goods such as car batteries.

loans.use: Shop maintenance and purchase of additional goods

loans.name: Mamuna

texts.en:
Mamuna S. is married with five children who have completed school. She is a 44-year-old businesswoman. She started in commerce six years ago, and she enjoys selling goods. She sells clothing materials and used clothes.

Mamuna believes in hard work and dedication. She has gained lots of marketing experience, making her one of the more successful traders in Obuasi market. She believes the loan would provide her more with capital to purchase more stocks of clothing materials to serve her customers. Mamuna S. belongs to the group called Gift Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee and provide support for one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of clothing materials and used clothes.

loans.name: Angel

texts.es: EL SEÑOR A. C. ES UNA PERSONA MUY TRABAJADORA Y CON MUCHAS GANAS DE TENER UN HOGAR MAS COMODO, ES CHOFER DE TRANSPORTE ESCOLAR Y MEDIANTE ESTO EL OBTIENE SUS INGRESOS; SOLICITA ESTE PRESTAMO PARA COLOCAR SU TECHO DE LAMINA PARA SU "CASITA", EL Y SU ESPOSA SON PERSONAS GRANDES DE EDAD PERO CON MUCHAS GANAS DE VIVIR Y DE SALIR ADELANTE.
texts.en:
Sr. A. C. is a hard-working man with a strong desire to own a more comfortable home. He makes a living as a school bus driver. He's applying for this loan to install a laminate sheet roof on his "casita". He and his wife have many years between them but they haven't stopped wanting to improve their lives.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Install laminate sheet roof.

loans.name: Vuthy

texts.en:
Mr. Vuthy K., 40, and his wife, Mrs. Nare K., 37, live about fifteen kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They married in 1992 and have four sons. All of them study at the local school.

Vuthy has been a policeman in Phnom Penh for twenty years and has been a motor taxi driver for six years. He operates his motor taxi business when he finishes work in Phnom Penh City. Mrs. Nare has been a garment factory worker for two years.  Vuthy is requesting a loan of US $800 to purchase a motorbike to replace his old one.  This will enable him to drive to work and operate his motor taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to replace his current one.

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en: Mrs. Chanthy N. is a villager in Pong Toek Village, Takeo Province. She owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn her living. Her husband, Mr. Mon Neng, helps her on the plantation. They have three children who all attend the local school. Although Chanthy and her husband have two different businesses, they still cannot provide better conditions for their family. In order to improve their standard of living, Chanthy decided to ask for a loan to buy steel to build a house and she hopes to make her household in better condition to live in. Her husband is shown on the right of photo.

loans.use: Chanthy would like to buy steel to build her family's house.

loans.name: Sary's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sary C. is the village bank president of nine people who all live in Svay Khoy village in Kampong Chhnang province. She sells fish in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it; thus, she decided to request a loan to buy more fish for her business. She hopes to increase her income and provide a better life for her family. Her husband, Mr. Sao Kouy, is a driver. Mrs. Sary C. is 33 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are attending the local school, while the other is only three years old.

One of the group members, Mrs. Leng K., could not be in the picture, so her husband is pictured instead.  

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest of have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term ( EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.
